newsitem.title: JAPAN: Surge in Japan surplus may have peaked - economists.
newsitem.headline: Surge in Japan surplus may have peaked - economists.

text.p: Growth in Japan's trade surplus is likely to have peaked, and the contentious indicator may show a much smaller year-on-year increase later this year, economists said on Monday.

The Finance Ministry announced on Monday morning that Jpaan posted a customs-cleared trade surplus of 453.20 billion yen ($4.01 billion) in the first 20 days of June, up 129.3 percent from the same period a year earlier. Exports rose 19.1 percent year-on-year, while imports increased 8.5 percent.

Economists said temporary factors such as an increase in Japan's consumption tax on April 1 were still affecting imports, but prospects of a slowdown in the U.S. economy may help curb Japan's exports, slowing growth in the overall surplus.

"We've seen the worst surge in trade surpluses behind us. We are probably going to see a decline in the trade surplus in the second half of this year on the back of a rebound in import growth," said Andrew Shipley, an economist at Schroder Securities (Japan).

Michael Hartnett, senior economist at Merrill Lynch Japan, said: "Possibly more of a surprise is the pickup in import growth we saw this morning -- 8.5 percent year-on-year -- I think that's the strongest number in year-on-year terms since February 1996, so that might quell some fears that the trade surplus is going to go inexorably upwards."
